{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2990110,"name":"","username":"ilgazegeoz","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ilgazegeoz/{size}/162749_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-12T18:39:37.730Z","cooked":"

What are the rpm values ​​you use for shooting mechanism?

Additionally, is there a simulation we can use to find the angle for shooting?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2022-01-12T18:39:37.730Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":93,"reads":166,"readers_count":165,"score":513.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":399931,"topic_slug":"rpm-for-shooting-mechanism-and-simulation","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49709,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/rpm-for-shooting-mechanism-and-simulation/399931/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":2990112,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-12T18:41:59.347Z","cooked":"

This is the land of experimentation. There are too many unknowns around energy transfer, compression, wheel diameter, coefficient of friction, and a host of other things.

As far as the simulation is concerned…

Finding Allowable Error in Shooting Technical
[proj_motion] I thought it would be fun to make a projectile motion simulator that looks for the possible space of position and exit velocity that is able to launch cargo into the Upper Hub. This python program generates an interactive matplotlib program that you can play around with, and maybe this could help with determining where/how to shoot cargo given different confidence levels in shoot angle and speed. For example, if you aren’t very confident in your ability to control the speed, find…

Here is a thread with a lot of rapid react resources, including some shooting calculators.

This is an excel spreadsheet where you can enter several parameters and get a graphical result. (Note it doesn’t render properly in google sheets, you need to use excel for full functionality)

^They are correct that the land of experimentation will be your friend.
A nice place to start would be to look at a projectile motion calculator to give you some idea of what different changes could do to your system, as well as give some background to the basics of what type of motion you’ll be looking for.
Here is one for reference:
https://amesweb.info/Physics/Projectile-Motion-Calculator.aspx

My team just built a quick prototype to test because factors like the rpm and compression are gonna be slightly different for different game elements, and they can also be kind of tough to get an accurate simulation of.
